flow.context: Calling Kristy Doggett — co-owner and manager of iTrip Beaches of Alabama, an iTrip franchise covering Gulf Shores, Orange Beach, and Fort Morgan since 2010. She handles accounting and back-of-house operations, meaning she directly feels the financial impact of missed damage and failed deposit claims. Co-owns with Lynn Humphries who runs front-of-house and reservations. No inspection software confirmed publicly — no Breezeway, no Matterport. Unit count unknown but likely a smaller operation competing in a market with 350-plus unit players like Beachball Properties and Young's Suncoast. Beach properties mean heavy wear from sand, salt air, humidity, and seasonal party crowds. Calling her cell at (251) 747-2146. Strongest connection: Sam works with Gulf Coast vacation rental managers and is a lifelong surfer and fisherman — Gulf Shores is a premier fishing and beach destination.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Kristy, I work with a few other vacation rental managers along the Gulf Coast — it's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet up on the desk energy. Slow, conversational. Sound like you belong in her world. Let her answer before you say anything else.

branches.label: No, I haven't heard of you
I'm busy / not a good time
What are you selling? / Skeptical tone

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason I'm calling is — I've been working with a couple other vacation rental owners in beach markets, and the same thing keeps coming up. Their cleaners are snapping turnover photos — dozens per unit — but nobody actually has time to look through them all carefully. So damage slips through, a guest checks in, something's already broken or missing, and now you're eating that repair cost because you can't prove it happened on the last guest's watch. One owner told me she was losing thousands every season just on stuff that was literally in the photos but nobody caught in time.
heard_no.note: Paint the picture vividly. Slow down on 'nobody actually has time to look through them.' PAUSE after 'nobody caught in time.' Let it land. Do NOT rush to the solution.

branches.label: Yeah that's definitely a problem / shares her own experience
Okay so what do you do exactly?
We're pretty good on that / not really an issue for us
I'm not really the right person / talk to Lynn

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Genuine curiosity. Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge to discovery or the pain trigger naturally.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow or later this week?
bad_timing.note: Don't over-apologize. Keep it light. Try to get a specific day and time for the callback.

branches.label: Sure, try me at a specific time

bad_timing_lock.label: LOCK CALLBACK TIME
bad_timing_lock.say: Perfect — I'll try you [repeat their day and time]. Talk to you then, Kristy.
bad_timing_lock.note: Repeat the exact time back. Calendar it immediately. Don't try to pitch right now.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean, it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Self-aware humor about the cold call. Low pressure. You're asking for 30 seconds, not 30 minutes.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: Last attempt before exit. Split the objection. You're giving her an out while learning what's really going on.

pain_trigger_short.label: SHORT PAIN TRIGGER — 30 SECONDS
pain_trigger_short.say: Appreciate it. Quick version — I work with vacation rental managers who are collecting turnover photos but don't have time to actually review them all. Damage gets missed, the next guest checks in, and now you're eating the repair cost. We built an AI that goes through every photo automatically and catches what humans miss. Would you be open to taking a quick look when I'm not interrupting your day?
pain_trigger_short.note: Compressed version. Pain plus solution plus CTA in 30 seconds. You promised 30 seconds — honor that.

warm_response.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING
warm_response.say: Yeah it's a real thing. So I'm curious — what does your turnover process look like right now? Are your cleaners taking photos after every turn, or is it more of a spot-check situation?
warm_response.note: She showed interest. STOP SELLING. Ask questions now. Listen. Take notes. Let her talk about her world.

branches.label: Describes their process with photos or checklists
We don't really do formal photos / pretty informal
Yeah we take photos but complains about something

discovery_process.label: DIG INTO THEIR PROCESS
discovery_process.say: Got it. And when something does slip through — like damage shows up after a guest checks in — how do you guys handle that? Is it coming out of your pocket, or are you able to go back to the previous guest?
discovery_process.note: You're looking for the financial pain. Kristy handles accounting and back-of-house — this is her world. Let her tell you where the money leaks.

branches.label: We eat the cost most of the time / hard to prove
We have a process but it's not perfect
We're pretty good at catching it

discovery_no_photos.label: NO FORMAL PHOTO PROCESS
discovery_no_photos.say: That's actually really common with smaller teams — everybody's running around during turnover, there's no time to document everything. Out of curiosity, when a homeowner asks what happened to my couch or a guest says something was already broken when they got there — what do you fall back on?
discovery_no_photos.note: No judgment. Frame it as totally normal. The pain lives in the lack of proof when disputes come up.

branches.label: It's a headache / we don't have great documentation
We handle it case by case / figure it out

discovery_pain_confirmed.label: PAIN CONFIRMED — BRIDGE TO SOLUTION
discovery_pain_confirmed.say: Yeah that's exactly what I keep hearing. So what we built — honestly it's pretty simple — RapidEye plugs into whatever photo workflow you've already got, and our AI goes through every single photo automatically. It flags damage, missing items, staging issues — stuff a human eye would catch if they had 30 minutes per unit, but nobody does. One line of defense between turnover and check-in that doesn't require any extra work from your team.
discovery_pain_confirmed.note: One breath. Don't go deep on features. Watch for her reaction. Then go straight to the CTA.

branches.label: We're too small for that / not sure we need it
Sounds cool but not right now

discovery_challenge.label: THEY SAY THEY'RE GOOD — DIG DEEPER
discovery_challenge.say: That's great — honestly most folks I talk to in the Gulf Shores market say the opposite, so you're ahead of the curve. What are you guys using? Is it a software thing or more of a manual process your team's built out?
discovery_challenge.note: Compliment them genuinely. Then get curious. If they have a real system, learn what it is. If it's manual, there's still a play.

branches.label: Describes a software tool like Breezeway or Track
It's manual / checklists / our team just knows
Something basic like a shared photo album or email

challenge_manual.label: MANUAL PROCESS — FIND THE GAP
challenge_manual.say: Yeah and honestly that works until it doesn't, right? Like during peak season when you're flipping units back to back and the team's stretched thin — that's usually when stuff gets missed. Is summer your craziest time or do you guys stay pretty steady year-round?
challenge_manual.note: Gulf Shores peak is absolutely summer. Beach rentals have insane turnover volume May through September. This is where manual processes crack.

branches.label: Summer is nuts / peak season is intense
We manage it okay / stays pretty steady

peak_season_pain.label: PEAK SEASON PAIN
peak_season_pain.say: Yeah that's what I figured — Gulf Shores in the summer, you're probably doing back-to-back Saturday turns, right? That's exactly when our other clients said things were falling through the cracks. Would you be open to seeing how a couple other beach market managers are handling it? Not a sales pitch — literally just a 15-minute walkthrough of what they're doing differently with their turnover photos.
peak_season_pain.note: Tie the CTA directly to peak season prep. She'll want to be ready before summer hits. Make it feel like peer insight, not a demo.

solution_pitch.label: SOLUTION — ONE SENTENCE
solution_pitch.say: So real quick — we built RapidEye to automatically analyze the turnover photos your team's already taking. Our AI catches damage, missing items, staging problems — basically a second set of eyes on every single photo, every single turn, without adding any steps for your people.
solution_pitch.note: Keep it to two sentences max. Then go straight to the CTA. Do not feature-dump.

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue? It's like 15 minutes — I can show you exactly how it works with real turnover photos from beach properties.
cta_meeting.note: Low pressure. 15 minutes. Specific to beach properties so it feels directly relevant to her portfolio.

branches.label: Sure yeah I'd look at that
I'm not sure / let me think about it

nudge_meeting.label: GENTLE NUDGE
nudge_meeting.say: Totally fair. And honestly worst case you see what other beach market managers are doing with their inspection photos and steal some ideas. Even if RapidEye's not a fit, the 15 minutes won't be wasted. Would sometime next week work, or is the week after better?
nudge_meeting.note: Offer value beyond the product itself. Give two timeframe options instead of a yes-or-no question.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING — LOCK IT IN NOW
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up — does morning or afternoon work better for you?
book_meeting.note: Pick two specific days. Get the time nailed down NOW. Send the calendar invite while still on the phone. Don't hang up without a locked time.

branches.label: Let me check my calendar and get back to you

pin_down_meeting.label: PIN DOWN THE MEETING
pin_down_meeting.say: For sure — I'll shoot you an invite for Thursday at 10 your time and if that doesn't work just let me know and we'll move it around. Sound good?
pin_down_meeting.note: Don't leave it open-ended. Anchor a specific time. It's easier to reschedule an invite than to start from zero over email.

meeting_booked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — sending that over right now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Kristy. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING IMMEDIATELY. Send the calendar invite right now while you're still on the line. Be warm, brief, done.

deflect_price.label: PRICE QUESTION — DEFLECT TO MEETING
deflect_price.say: Good question — it honestly depends on how many units you're managing and what your turnover volume looks like. That's exactly what I'd walk you through in the demo — I can show you the pricing right alongside the ROI so it actually makes sense in context. Would you be open to a quick 15 minutes?
deflect_price.note: Never throw out a number on a cold call. Deflect to the meeting where you can frame value properly around her specific situation.

deflect_price_again.label: THEY INSIST ON PRICE
deflect_price_again.say: I hear you. For a beach market operation your size, most of our clients are spending less per unit than what one missed damage claim costs them. But it really depends on your volume — that's why the 15 minutes is worth it. I'll lay it all out transparently, no surprises.
deflect_price_again.note: Give a value anchor, not a dollar figure. Push for the meeting one more time. If she still resists, pivot to email.

objection_not_interested.label: NOT INTERESTED — MIYAGI METHOD
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. Honestly I should have assumed you'd already be all set — otherwise you probably would have reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that this just isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you hate cold calls and I caught you at a bad time?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise her by not pushing back. Then split the objection into multiple choice. You're looking for what's REALLY going on underneath.

branches.label: Not focused on it / not a priority right now
Bad timing / I hate cold calls
We already have something in place

not_priority_reframe.label: NOT A PRIORITY — REFRAME
not_priority_reframe.say: Totally fair. And you're probably not buying anything right now — I respect that. But when peak season ramps up and turnover volume spikes, the managers who already know what's out there are the ones who move fastest. Would you be open to a quick look — not to buy anything, just so it's on your radar before summer hits?
not_priority_reframe.note: Sell the test drive. Position it as preparation, not a purchase. Summer peak season is her natural pressure point.

branches.label: Okay I guess that makes sense

bad_timing_recovery.label: BAD TIMING RECOVERY
bad_timing_recovery.say: Ha — totally fair, and I appreciate you being straight with me. Would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again next week? I promise I'll keep it short.
bad_timing_recovery.note: Light humor. Don't push hard. Just get a callback window and move on.

branches.label: Sure try me at a specific time

objection_have_vendor.label: ALREADY HAVE A VENDOR OR PROCESS
objection_have_vendor.say: That makes total sense — with properties along the Gulf Coast you'd have to have something in place. Just so I don't waste your time — is it that you're fully covered and happy with what you've got, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a headache?
objection_have_vendor.note: Split the objection. 'Happy' versus 'switching is hard' are very different problems. Listen carefully to which one she picks.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have
Switching would be a pain / not worth the hassle
It's not perfect but it works well enough

vendor_happy.label: HAPPY WITH CURRENT VENDOR
vendor_happy.say: Love to hear that — seriously. Out of curiosity, what are you guys using? I'm always trying to learn what's working in different markets.
vendor_happy.note: Genuine curiosity. If she names a tool, log it. Don't trash-talk the competitor. Learn and exit gracefully.

branches.label: Names a tool or describes their system

vendor_learn_and_exit.label: LEARN AND PLANT A SEED
vendor_learn_and_exit.say: Got it — that's good to know. Well if anything ever changes or you want a second opinion on what's out there, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time, Kristy.
vendor_learn_and_exit.note: Don't push. Plant the seed. Leave on excellent terms. Log what tool they use in your CRM for future reference.

vendor_switching.label: SWITCHING IS THE CONCERN
vendor_switching.say: Yeah totally — the last thing you need is another migration headache. Here's the thing though — RapidEye actually layers on top of whatever you're already using. It's not a rip-and-replace. So if your current tool handles scheduling and checklists, we just analyze the photos that are already flowing through it. Would it be worth 15 minutes to see if it even makes sense alongside what you've got?
vendor_switching.note: Remove the switching fear immediately. RapidEye adds to their stack, doesn't replace it. This is a key differentiator.

branches.label: Okay that's different / I'd look at that

vendor_imperfect.label: CURRENT PROCESS ISN'T PERFECT
vendor_imperfect.say: Yeah — that's what I hear a lot actually. Like it works 90 percent of the time but it's that other 10 percent that ends up costing you. What's the biggest gap you see with it?
vendor_imperfect.note: She just cracked the door open. Ask what's broken. Let her sell herself on the need. Take notes on exactly what she says — you'll use this in the demo.

branches.label: Describes the gap or specific pain point
I don't know it's just not great

objection_too_small.label: TOO SMALL OBJECTION
objection_too_small.say: I hear you — and honestly with a smaller portfolio every missed damage claim hits harder, right? You don't have the volume to absorb it the way a 500-unit company does. That's actually where our clients see the biggest per-unit ROI. Would it be worth a quick look?
objection_too_small.note: Flip the objection. Smaller equals each miss matters MORE, not less. This speaks directly to Kristy's accounting and back-of-house mindset.

objection_timing.label: NOT THE RIGHT TIME
objection_timing.say: Totally get it. This one's on me — if you were totally ready you probably would've reached out. Just out of curiosity — is it that there's just too much going on right now, or is it more that you'd want to wait until closer to peak season to evaluate something like this?
objection_timing.note: Split the timing objection. If it's seasonal, you can anchor the meeting to pre-season preparation.

branches.label: Too much going on right now
Would look at it closer to summer

timing_seasonal.label: SEASONAL TIMING — ANCHOR TO PREP
timing_seasonal.say: That makes total sense. Our other beach market clients usually want everything dialed in before the summer rush starts — so they're typically evaluating now and going live by May. Would it make sense to do a quick intro call in the next couple weeks so you're not scrambling when things ramp up?
timing_seasonal.note: Create urgency around pre-season preparation. Gulf Shores summer starts ramping in late May. Position the meeting as getting ahead of the curve.

branches.label: Reach back out in a month or two

timing_followup.label: SCHEDULE FUTURE FOLLOWUP
timing_followup.say: For sure — I'll put a reminder in for [the month she suggested]. I'll shoot you a quick email now so you've got my info when the time comes. Sound good?
timing_followup.note: Lock in the follow-up timing. Send the email today so your name is in her inbox when you call back. Set the CRM reminder.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over. One quick question so it's not just another generic email sitting in your inbox — would it be more useful to see how it works with actual turnover photos, or would you rather see the ROI breakdown on what missed damage typically costs in a beach market?
send_email.note: Accept the request but ask one tailoring question. Kristy is back-of-house and accounting-minded so she'll likely want the ROI angle. Include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email.

branches.label: Show me how it works with photos

send_email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL AND CLOSE
send_email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll send that over to your iTrip email this afternoon. I'll include a couple times to connect in case you want to dig deeper after you see it. Appreciate your time, Kristy.
send_email_confirm.note: Send to [email protected]. Include two specific time options for a follow-up call. Follow up by phone in 3 business days if no response. Tailor the email to what she asked for.

referral_redirect.label: WRONG PERSON — REDIRECT
referral_redirect.say: Totally — appreciate you telling me. Who on your team would typically own the inspection or turnover process? Would that be Lynn, or is there someone else who handles that side?
referral_redirect.note: You know Lynn Humphries is the other co-owner and handles front-of-house. Name-drop her naturally to show you've done your homework. Get the right person and contact info.

branches.label: Names someone else on the team
Actually we both handle it / you can talk to me

referral_lynn.label: REFERRED TO LYNN
referral_lynn.say: Perfect — is the best way to reach Lynn through the main office line, or does she have a direct number? And would it help if I mentioned you pointed me her way?
referral_lynn.note: Get Lynn's direct contact info. Using Kristy's name as an intro when you call Lynn makes it a warm call instead of cold.

branches.label: Gives Lynn's number or says use main line
I'll have her call you back

referral_other.label: REFERRED TO SOMEONE ELSE
referral_other.say: Awesome — what's the best way to reach them? And would it help if I mentioned you pointed me their way?
referral_other.note: Get name, title, phone number, and email. Use Kristy's name as social proof when reaching out.

referral_close.label: CLOSE THE REFERRAL
referral_close.say: Really appreciate that, Kristy. I'll reach out to them and mention you sent me. Thanks for your time — have a good one.
referral_close.note: Warm and brief. Call the referral the same day while the connection is fresh. Log all details.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER — SOMEONE ELSE ANSWERS
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to Kristy? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Don't pitch. Don't explain. First name only for both of you. Confident and casual like you're expected. Wait for them to ask before giving more.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER WANTS MORE CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other vacation rental managers along the coast. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still don't pitch. Give just enough context to sound legitimate. Redirect back to the transfer request.

branches.label: Let me see if she's available
She's busy or in a meeting

gatekeeper_unavailable.label: GATEKEEPER — NOT AVAILABLE
gatekeeper_unavailable.say: No worries — when's the best time to catch her? I'll try back then.
gatekeeper_unavailable.note: Get a specific time window. Avoid leaving a voicemail if you can — a live callback is always better.

branches.label: Gives a time or says try back later
I can take a message for her

gatekeeper_callback.label: GATEKEEPER — CALLBACK SCHEDULED
gatekeeper_callback.say: Perfect — I'll try her then. Thanks for your help.
gatekeeper_callback.note: Call back at exactly the time they gave you. Note the gatekeeper's name if they shared it — use it next time.

gatekeeper_message.label: GATEKEEPER — LEAVE A MESSAGE
gatekeeper_message.say: Sure — just let her know Sam Parks called. I work with vacation rental managers on their inspection workflows. She can reach me at [your number]. Appreciate it.
gatekeeper_message.note: Keep the message short and vague enough to create curiosity. Don't pitch in the voicemail. Call back regardless in 24 hours.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time, Kristy.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Stay warm and genuine. Log the outcome and set a 90-day follow-up reminder in your CRM. She may come around later.
